Just a random thought I had about evolving biped gaits: Have you considered=

first evolving a quadruped gait, then switching the fitness function to on=
e
that's similar to the quadruped fitness function but has additional rewar=
ds
for spending more time on two legs? Since that's how it seems evolution
=
worked out in the real world, maybe it would make it easier here.

2009/2/1=
5 petar_chervenski <petar_chervenski@...>

>   Hi Jeff.
>
> Here is m=
y opinion about the 4 hypothesis you suggested.
>
> >1. Biped gaits are har=
der to evolve than quadruped gaits
>
> Definitely true! :) While robots wit=
h 3+ legs are generally stable,
> biped robots have trouble keeping their b=
alance. My zero-g experiment
> with novelty search showed that getting an o=
scillation pattern that
> resembles a walking human is not a big problem. B=
ut add gravity and it
> falls every time. Kind of frustrating :/
> It is po=
ssible to get a good biped walking behavior with HyperNEAT or
> just regula=
r NEAT, but it is hard to get results in practice.. Tyler
> Streeter has do=
ne such experiments, in fact my own experiments were
> inspired by his work=
.
> It is interesting that NEAT performs well even in cases of only one
> l=
eg. Remember that NEAT Hopper demo?
> So I guess the failure of my experime=
nts is not because it is
> incredibly hard to evolve good biped walking gai=
t. It is hard indeed,
> but not that hard :)
>
> >2. The sine wave I provid=
ed made it really easy to evolve periodic
> >gaits.
>
> Yes, inputting just=
 a sine wave to the substrate is something clever
> and I never thought of =
that. I actually prefer leaky integrators
> because a CTRNN substrate made =
up by leaky integrators doesn't need
> any inputs to make oscillations. It =
doesn't need inputs and timing at
> all. The time constant range in the lea=
ky integrator substrate becomes
> the thing that is as important as the per=
iod of the sine wave in your
> system.
>
> >3. Leaky integrators hurt perfo=
rmance for some reason.
>
> Probably. The main reason behind why leaky inte=
grator-based substrates
> may perform worse is because not all networks are=
 guaranteed to
> oscillate. Some just stabilize forever. Getting oscillatio=
n with leaky
> integrator networks is like a small short-term challenge of =
its own.
> :) Inputting a sine wave explicitly makes the whole thing differ=
ent.
> But there is an interesting observation of leaky integrator substrat=
es
> evolving with HyperNEAT. The neural activity itself appears
> distribu=
ted in a complexifying geometric pattern. The time constants
> and biases o=
f the neurons are generated by a 2D/3D spatial CPPN.
>
> >4. I used a PID-b=
ased setup, where the target angle was the output of
> the
> >neural net (a=
nd not the force to be applied).
>
> I used the same :) The outputs are all=
 the target joint angle rescaled
> to min/max angle of the particular joint=
. But I tried applying forces
> and even direct angular velocities. It is i=
nteresting, it has
> different dynamics but the PID-based setup is closest =
to reality
> anyway :)
>
> Peter
>
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <neat%40ya=
hoogroups.com>, Jeff Clune <jclune@...>
> wrote:
> >
> > > Very interesting=
 paper! :)
> >
> > Thanks. I'm glad you enjoyed it.
> >
> > > It reminds me=
 about the experiments I made with HyperNEAT for
> > > controlling biped ro=
bots. Did you try using leaky-integrator based
> > > neurons for the substr=
ate?
> > > I found them very useful for generating
> > > oscillation patter=
ns. Substrates of leaky integrators with tanh()
> > > activation functions =
produce oscillations much easier than others.
> > > Hm.. I should really tr=
y with robots with 3 legs or more. Getting
> > > biped walking with HyperNE=
AT is perhaps too ambitious right now.
> >
> > I have thought a lot about y=
our biped experiment. I'd be really
> interested
> > in hearing your opinio=
n, and that of anyone else on this list, as to
> why
> > your results were =
so different from mine. I found that it did not
> take that
> > much tuning=
 to get HyperNEAT to evolve really good quadruped gaits.
> But, as
> > you =
note, it was much harder to evolve gaits in your biped setup.
> >
> > I can=
 suggest a few hypotheses as to what explains the difference.
> These are
>=
 > not mutually exclusive, and it might not be the case that any one of
> t=
hem
> > explains most of the difference, but instead that they add up to th=
e
> > difference.
> >
> > 1) Biped gaits are harder to evolve than quadrupe=
d gaits
> > 2) The sine wave I provided made it really easy to evolve perio=
dic
> gaits.
> > 3) Leaky integrators hurt performance for some reason
> > =
4) I used a PID-based setup, where the target angle was the output
> of the=

> > neural net (and not the force to be applied)
> >
> > There are other d=
ifferences of course, such as the inputs and the
> number of
> > hidden nod=
es.
> >
> > I'll make a few comments on each hypothesis.
> >
> > 1) Biped g=
aits are harder to evolve than quadruped gaits.
> >
> > This would be easy =
to test by simply trying a biped with my setup.
> > Unfortunately, I have s=
ome other obligations that will prevent me
> from
> > testing this anytime =
soon, but if you (or anyone else) would like to
> give it
> > a try, that w=
ould be cool. I can send you the code I used. One would
> just
> > need to =
change the quadruped into a biped. Alternately, you could
> try to
> > mimi=
c my setup in your "Ultimate NEAT" ;-).
> >
> > I do have access to a huge =
computing cluster. So, if someone makes
> the code
> > modifications to my =
setup (which I know compiles on our cluster) and
> sends
> > them to me, I =
can do a batch of runs.
> >
> > 2) The sine wave I provided made it really =
easy to evolve periodic
> gaits
> >
> > This would be an easy test. You cou=
ld just plug a sine as an input
> into your
> > biped. Note: I found that t=
he period of the sine wave made a huge
> > difference. If I made it too fas=
t or too slow, evolution basically
> ignored
> > the signal. Within the ran=
ge of periods that worked, I found that I
> got
> > different types of gait=
s with different period speeds. With slower
> periods,
> > I observed cool =
tortoise-like gaits with left-right symmetry. With
> medium
> > periods, I =
got the gaits in the paper. With faster periods, I saw
> slightly
> > more =
frantic versions of the gaits in the paper.
> >
> > As a side note, I tried=
 to evolve the period for a short while and
> it was a
> > miserable failur=
e. I'd like to try that again, and would be
> interested to
> > hear people=
's thoughts as to why it failed. Maybe I'll describe that
> attempt
> > in =
another email. If someone out there is curious, let me know and
> I'll send=

> > it out sooner rather than later.
> >
> > 3) Leaky integrators hurt per=
formance for some reason.
> >
> > I did not try leaky integrators. Did you =
ever try your setup without
> them?
> >
> > I did not try them because the =
default sigmoid neurons worked so
> well out of
> > the box that I did not =
experiment with alternatives. Both Ken
> (during
> > preliminary conversati=
ons about the paper) and one of the papers'
> reviewers
> > asked about lea=
ky integrators, so there is clearly some interest out
> there
> > in seeing=
 how leaky integrators would compare to the neurons
> > we used in the pape=
r.
> >
> > Do most of you feel leaky integrators would perform better? Why?=
 I
> have
> > never worked with them, nor do I know that much about them, s=
o I
> don't have
> > great instincts on this front. Is it possible that the=
y could have
> made
> > things worse in Petar's setup?
> >
> > It would be =
cool to test them out in my setup. Again, I won't be
> able to get
> > to t=
his in the near future so if someone out there wants to swap
> them in and
=
> > give it a go, that would be interesting.
> >
> > 4) I used a PID-based =
setup, where the target angle was the output
> of the
> > neural net (and n=
ot the force to be applied).
> >
> > I could not figure out whether your se=
tup did this as well. What
> were the
> > outputs in your system?
> > -----=
----
> >
> > Do you think any/all of these hypotheses explain the differenc=
e in
> results?
> > What other likely hypothesis am I missing (I am sure th=
ere are
> lots).
> >
> > Thanks again for checking out the paper,
> > Jeff
=
> >
> > PS. Tripods would be fun. I also think adding feet and a flexible
>=
 torso
> > would be interesting.
> >
> >
> >
> > >
> > > Peter
> > >
> > > =
--- In neat@yahoogroups.com <neat%40yahoogroups.com>, Jeff Clune
> <jclune@=
> wrote:
> > >>
> > >> Hello all-
> > >>
> > >> Ever since I first understo=
od HyperNEAT I have wanted to see how
> it
> > > would
> > >> perform at co=
ntrolling legged robots.
> > >>
> > >> A paper I wrote on that subject was =
just accepted, so I can share
> it
> > > with
> > >> you now.
> > >>
> > >>=
 A copy of the paper, and videos of the simulated robots, can be
> > > obta=
ined
> > >> here:
> > >>
> > >>
> > >
> http://devolab.msu.edu/SupportDocs/=
EvolvingCoordinatedGaitsWithHyperNE
> > > AT
> > >>
> > >>
> > >> I hope yo=
u find it interesting. Please let me know what you
> think,
> > > or if you=

> > >> have any questions.
> > >>
> > >>
> > >> Here is the cite and abstr=
act:
> > >>
> > >> Clune, J., Beckmann, B. E., Ofria, C., & Pennock, R. T.
=
> > >> Evolving coordinated gaits with the HyperNEAT generative
> encoding.=

> > >>
> > >> Proceedings of the IEEE Congress on Evolutionary Computing
>=
 Special
> > > Section
> > >> on Evolutionary Robotics, 2009. Trondheim, No=
rway. To appear.
> > >>
> > >> Legged robots show promise for complex mobil=
ity tasks, such as
> > > navigating
> > >> rough terrain, but the design of=
 their control software is both
> > > challenging
> > >> and laborious. Tra=
ditional evolutionary algorithms can produce
> these
> > >> controllers, bu=
t require manual decomposition or other problem
> > >> simplification becau=
se conventionally-used direct encodings have
> > > trouble
> > >> taking ad=
vantage of a problem's regularities and symmetries. Such
> > > active
> > >=
> intervention is time consuming, limits the range of potential
> > > solut=
ions, and
> > >> requires the user to possess a deep understanding of the
>=
 problem's
> > >> structure. This paper demonstrates that HyperNEAT, a new =
and
> > > promising
> > >> generative encoding for evolving neural networks=
, can evolve
> > > quadruped gaits
> > >> without manually decomposing the =
problem. Analyses suggest that
> > > HyperNEAT is
> > >> successful because=
 it employs a generative encoding that can more
> > > easily
> > >> reuse p=
henotypic modules. It is also one of the first
> > > neuroevolutionary
> > =
>> algorithms that exploits a problem's geometric symmetries, which
> may
>=
 > > aid its
> > >> performance. We compare HyperNEAT to FT-NEAT, a direct =
encoding
> > > control, and
> > >> find that HyperNEAT is able to evolve im=
pressive quadruped gaits
> and
> > > vastly
> > >> outperforms FT-NEAT. Com=
parative analyses reveal that HyperNEAT
> > > individuals
> > >> are more h=
olistically affected by genetic operators, resulting in
> > > better
> > >>=
 coordination of the quadruped's legs. Overall, the results
> suggest
> > >=
 that
> > >> HyperNEAT is a powerful algorithm for evolving control systems=

> for
> > > complex,
> > >> yet regular, devices, such as robots.
> > >>
>=
 > >>
> > >>
> > >>
> > >>
> > >>
> > >> Cheers,
> > >> Jeff Clune
> > >>
>=
 > >> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
> > >>
> > >> jclune=
@
> > >>
> > >
> > >
> > >
> >
>
>

Just a random thought I had about evolving biped gaits: Have you considered=
 first evolving a quadruped gait, then switching the fitness function to on=
e that's similar to the quadruped fitness function but has additional r=
ewards for spending more time on two legs? Since that's how it seems ev=
olution worked out in the real world, maybe it would make it easier here.<b=
r>
<br><div class=3D"gmail_quote">2009/2/15 petar_chervenski <span dir=3D"l=
tr"><<a href=3D"mailto:petar_chervenski@...">petar_chervenski@yaho=
o.com</a>></span><br><blockquote class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"border-l=
eft: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); margin: 0pt 0pt 0pt 0.8ex; padding-left:=
 1ex;">










<div style=3D"background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">


<=
div style=3D"width: 655px;">
<div style=3D"margin: 0pt; padding: 0pt 25px 0=
pt 0pt; width: 470px; float: left;">


    <div>
            <p>Hi Jeff.<br=
>
<br>
Here is my opinion about the 4 hypothesis you suggested. <br></p><di=
v class=3D"Ih2E3d">
<br>
>1. Biped gaits are harder to evolve than quadr=
uped gaits<br>
<br></div>
Definitely true! :) While robots with 3+ legs are=
 generally stable, <br>
biped robots have trouble keeping their balance. My=
 zero-g experiment <br>
with novelty search showed that getting an oscillat=
ion pattern that <br>
resembles a walking human is not a big problem. But a=
dd gravity and it <br>
falls every time. Kind of frustrating :/ <br>
It is =
possible to get a good biped walking behavior with HyperNEAT or <br>
just r=
egular NEAT, but it is hard to get results in practice.. Tyler <br>
Streete=
r has done such experiments, in fact my own experiments were <br>
inspired =
by his work. <br>
It is interesting that NEAT performs well even in cases o=
f only one <br>
leg. Remember that NEAT Hopper demo? <br>
So I guess the fa=
ilure of my experiments is not because it is <br>
incredibly hard to evolve=
 good biped walking gait. It is hard indeed, <br>
but not that hard :) <br>=
<div class=3D"Ih2E3d">
<br>
>2. The sine wave I provided made it really =
easy to evolve periodic <br>
>gaits.<br>
<br></div>
Yes, inputting just =
a sine wave to the substrate is something clever <br>
and I never thought o=
f that. I actually prefer leaky integrators <br>
because a CTRNN substrate =
made up by leaky integrators doesn't need <br>
any inputs to make oscil=
lations. It doesn't need inputs and timing at <br>
all. The time consta=
nt range in the leaky integrator substrate becomes <br>
the thing that is a=
s important as the period of the sine wave in your <br>
system. <br>
<br>
&=
gt;3. Leaky integrators hurt performance for some reason.<br>
<br>
Probably=
. The main reason behind why leaky integrator-based substrates <br>
may per=
form worse is because not all networks are guaranteed to <br>
oscillate. So=
me just stabilize forever. Getting oscillation with leaky <br>
integrator n=
etworks is like a small short-term challenge of its own. <br>
:) Inputting =
a sine wave explicitly makes the whole thing different. <br>
But there is a=
n interesting observation of leaky integrator substrates <br>
evolving with=
 HyperNEAT. The neural activity itself appears <br>
distributed in a comple=
xifying geometric pattern. The time constants <br>
and biases of the neuron=
s are generated by a 2D/3D spatial CPPN. <br><div class=3D"Ih2E3d">
<br>
&g=
t;4. I used a PID-based setup, where the target angle was the output of <br=
>
the<br>
>neural net (and not the force to be applied).<br>
<br></div>
=
I used the same :) The outputs are all the target joint angle rescaled <br>=

to min/max angle of the particular joint. But I tried applying forces <br>=

and even direct angular velocities. It is interesting, it has <br>
differe=
nt dynamics but the PID-based setup is closest to reality <br>
anyway :) <b=
r><div><div></div><div class=3D"Wj3C7c">
<br>
Peter<br>
<br>

st or too slow, evolution basically <br>

ann, B. E., Ofria, C., & Pennock, R. T.<br>

encoding.<br>

Special<br>

> &g=
t;> Legged robots show promise for complex mobility tasks, such as<br>
&=
gt; > navigating<br>
> >> rough terrain, but the design of thei=
r control software is both<br>
> > challenging<br>
> >> and =
laborious. Traditional evolutionary algorithms can produce <br>
these<br>
&=
gt; >> controllers, but require manual decomposition or other problem=
<br>
> >> simplification because conventionally-used direct encodi=
ngs have<br>
> > trouble<br>
> >> taking advantage of a prob=
lem's regularities and symmetries. Such<br>
> > active<br>
> &=
gt;> intervention is time consuming, limits the range of potential<br>
&=
gt; > solutions, and<br>
> >> requires the user to possess a de=
ep understanding of the <br>
problem's<br>
> >> structure. Thi=
s paper demonstrates that HyperNEAT, a new and<br>
> > promising<br>
=
> >> generative encoding for evolving neural networks, can evolve<=
br>
> > quadruped gaits<br>
> >> without manually decomposin=
g the problem. Analyses suggest that<br>
> > HyperNEAT is<br>
> &g=
t;> successful because it employs a generative encoding that can more<br=
>
> > easily<br>
> >> reuse phenotypic modules. It is also o=
ne of the first<br>
> > neuroevolutionary<br>
> >> algorithm=
s that exploits a problem's geometric symmetries, which <br>
may<br>
&g=
t; > aid its<br>
> >> performance. We compare HyperNEAT to FT-N=
EAT, a direct encoding<br>
> > control, and<br>
> >> find th=
at HyperNEAT is able to evolve impressive quadruped gaits <br>
and<br>
>=
 > vastly<br>
> >> outperforms FT-NEAT. Comparative analyses re=
veal that HyperNEAT<br>
> > individuals<br>
> >> are more ho=
listically affected by genetic operators, resulting in<br>
> > better=
<br>
> >> coordination of the quadruped's legs. Overall, the r=
esults <br>
suggest<br>
> > that<br>
> >> HyperNEAT is a pow=
erful algorithm for evolving control systems <br>
for<br>
> > complex=
,<br>
> >> yet regular, devices, such as robots.<br>
